steps.title: Check for abnormal vaginal discharge.
steps.content: Check for abnormal vaginal discharge. Healthy women have vaginal discharge, which can vary in color, amount, and consistency over the course of the menstrual cycle. Abnormal discharge, however, can indicate cervicitis or another problem, so make an appointment with your doctor. [1] X Research source Because vaginal discharge can vary so much, “abnormal” can mean a variety of things and can be defined differently by different women. That said, pay particular attention to any vaginal discharge with an unusual odor, color, or appearance.

steps.title: Watch for spotting between menstrual periods and after sex.
steps.content: Watch for spotting between menstrual periods and after sex. Bleeding between your menstrual periods, or after sexual intercourse, could be a sign of cervicitis. Because the tissue is more delicate, an inflamed cervix bleeds more easily than a normal cervix. Call your doctor if you notice this symptom. [2] X Trustworthy Source Johns Hopkins Medicine Official resource database of the world-leading Johns Hopkins Hospital Go to source You may notice, in particular, that you have spotting after sexual intercourse. This can also be a symptom of cervicitis. Spotting during sexual intercourse can be a symptom of other issues besides cervicitis so you should get it checked regardless. Vaginal bleeding can also be a sign of ectopic pregnancy—but only when combined with other symptoms like severe abdominal pain, shoulder pain, and lightheadedness. If you’re experiencing these symptoms, seek medical attention immediately. Reader Poll: We asked 275 wikiHow readers and 59% of them agreed that they would immediately seek emergency medical care if they suspected an ectopic pregnancy. [Take Poll]

steps.title: Check for pain during sexual intercourse.
steps.content: Check for pain during sexual intercourse. Pain during intercourse, also known as dyspareunia, is a common symptom and can indicate a variety of problems, including cervicitis. Make an appointment with your doctor to discuss the issue (along with any other symptoms you may have). There’s no reason to assume that pain during intercourse is normal or unavoidable. [3] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source

steps.title: Look for a feeling of heaviness in your lower abdomen.
steps.content: Look for a feeling of heaviness in your lower abdomen. Some women with cervicitis experience an uncomfortable feeling of bloating, pressure, or heaviness in the lower abdomen. Make an appointment with your doctor if you have this problem. [4] X Trustworthy Source MedlinePlus Collection of medical information sourced from the US National Library of Medicine Go to source Heaviness in your lower abdomen can be a symptom of other medical issues. You should get it checked out whether or not you suspect you may have cervicitis.

steps.title: Know the common symptoms of co-infections.
steps.content: Know the common symptoms of co-infections. Women with cervicitis sometimes experience related inflammation in the vagina (causing vaginal itching, dryness, and discomfort during intercourse) or urinary tract (causing frequent urination, painful urination, and, sometimes, blood in the urine). [5] X Trustworthy Source MedlinePlus Collection of medical information sourced from the US National Library of Medicine Go to source These symptoms are not technically signs of cervicitis itself, but they do suggest co-infections, so see your doctor regardless.

steps.title: Be aware of the less common symptoms of cervicitis.
steps.content: Be aware of the less common symptoms of cervicitis. In addition to the symptoms above, there are some signs of cervicitis that occur very rarely, usually only in those few cases in which an infection starts as cervicitis as then spreads to the rest of the body. These symptoms include: [6] X Research source Nausea Vomiting Diarrhea A general feeling of sickness

steps.title: Make an appointment with your doctor.
steps.content: Make an appointment with your doctor. Do not attempt to diagnose cervicitis yourself. The symptoms are easily confused with other conditions, such as yeast infections, and more importantly, your cervicitis may have developed because of a serious infection, like an STI, which requires medical treatment. [7] X Research source

steps.title: Get a pelvic exam.
steps.content: Get a pelvic exam. Your doctor will likely perform a pelvic exam as a first step in diagnosing cervicitis. They will insert a speculum and observe your cervix, making note of any redness, ulcerations, inflammation, swelling, or abnormal discharge. [8] X Trustworthy Source Johns Hopkins Medicine Official resource database of the world-leading Johns Hopkins Hospital Go to source

steps.title: Schedule lab tests.
steps.content: Schedule lab tests. If your pelvic exam reveals signs of cervicitis, your doctor will order applicable lab tests, including a culture of your cervical discharge, a culture of the cervical cells themselves, and, if you are sexually active, tests for gonorrhea, chlamydia, and other sexually transmitted infections. [9] X Trustworthy Source Johns Hopkins Medicine Official resource database of the world-leading Johns Hopkins Hospital Go to source Depending on the results of these tests, understand that your doctor may order additional testing, including a possible biopsy or colposcopy (an examination with a special magnifying device) of the cervix.

steps.title: Get a diagnosis from your doctor.
steps.content: Get a diagnosis from your doctor. There are two basic categories of cervicitis: infectious and non-infectious. Infectious cervicitis is much more common than non-infectious cervicitis. Your doctor will tell you which type you have. [10] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source Infectious cervicitis develops due to a sexually transmitted infection (STI) like gonorrhea or chlamydia. The association between these STIs and infectious cervicitis is so strong, in fact, that your doctor may start treating you for STIs immediately, even before the specific diagnosis is confirmed. Non-infectious cervicitis is much less common. Causes include foreign objects, such as intrauterine devices (IUDs) and cervical caps; allergic reactions to latex, which can develop after intercourse using latex condoms; and douches and other vaginal washes. Your doctor may also refer to “acute” or “chronic” cervicitis. In general, acute cervicitis is infectious; chronic cervicitis is non-infectious.

steps.title: Take prescribed medication.
steps.content: Take prescribed medication. For infectious cervicitis, your doctor will probably prescribe antibiotics to treat infections like chlamydia or gonorrhea. Antiviral medications may be prescribed to treat conditions like genital herpes. They may also recommend taking hormones like progesterone and estrogen or, in rare cases, glucocorticosteroids, to help with inflammation. [11] X Research source Side effects of these medications include nausea, upset stomach, and fatigue. Your doctor should outline the side effects of these medications before prescribing them to you.

steps.title: Consider electrocauterization.
steps.content: Consider electrocauterization. For non-infectious cervicitis, antibiotic and antiviral medications will not eliminate the problem. Therefore, your doctor may suggest one of three surgical treatment options. The first, electrocauterization, is a surgical procedure in which a doctor removes unwanted tissue with electricity.

steps.title: Discuss cryosurgery with your doctor.
steps.content: Discuss cryosurgery with your doctor. Your doctor may also recommend cryosurgery for cases of non-infectious cervicitis. Cryosurgery (a word that comes from the Greek for “icy hand work”) involves the use of extreme cold to “freeze off” or eliminate abnormal tissue. [12] X Research source

steps.title: Consider laser therapy.
steps.content: Consider laser therapy. Your doctor may also recommend laser therapy for cases of non-infectious cervicitis. Laser therapy is the use of intense beams of light to burn, destroy, or precisely cut unwanted tissue. [13] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source

steps.title: Avoid irritating your vagina.
steps.content: Avoid irritating your vagina. While pursuing treatment options with your doctor, you can also take steps to minimize your discomfort. Avoid anything that might irritate your vagina or cervix: douches, vaginal rinses, harsh soaps, and sexual intercourse should all be eliminated. [14] X Trustworthy Source MedlinePlus Collection of medical information sourced from the US National Library of Medicine Go to source

steps.title: Abstain from sex until your treatment is complete.
steps.content: Abstain from sex until your treatment is complete. Depending on what kind of treatment you receive for your cervicitis, you may need to abstain from sex for up to a week after your therapy is done. Ask your doctor how long you should wait before having sexual intercourse again. [15] X Research source

steps.title: Inform your sexual partners.
steps.content: Inform your sexual partners. If your cervicitis is infectious, make sure your sexual partners also seek treatment. Be aware that even if they have no symptoms, they can be infected, and they can re-infect you, even after you’ve followed the treatment regimen recommended by your doctor. [16] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source For these reasons, it is important for both your health and that or your partner(s) that they seek treatment as well.
